Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient expresses feelings of guilt regarding their inability to be more present in their children's lives, feeling stuck and wanting to provide more support.
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient has been practicing mindfulness daily, which has helped reduce anxiety and improve focus. They feel more patient with friends and are actively trying to build connections despite the distance from their children.
Psychosocial History: The patient has reached out to their children, which was a meaningful experience, but it also brought up feelings of sadness and longing to be with them.
Current Functional Status: The patient reports being more patient and less stressed, indicating an improvement in their interactions with others.
Progress Evaluation: The patient feels better after discussing their feelings and has made significant progress in managing anxiety through mindfulness practices.
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient plans to send care packages to their children as a way to maintain connection and support.
Next Steps: The patient aims to send a care package by the end of the week, which will include thoughtful items like snacks and toys.
